subNodes.conversationText: There was a pile of bones in this part of the cave. It was hard to say how long they'd been here.

The heap was once a single skeleton. Part of the skull was missing, and the rest was crushed. This person had met a violent end. Moldering rags clung to the bones. The pile made <FirstName> uneasy. Did Tilen know about it? Was this the source of his apprehension?

<He/She> felt a wave of repulsion and stepped back as if struck. The bones were strewn with charms against witchcraft. Very old charms, but still potent. Powdered hexbane, pages from witch hunters' tracts, alder branches tied into X's with leathern cords.
The parchment was moldy but still legible. The writing on it was in a rough, unskilled hand. This is what it said:
May no WITCH disturb this man's BONES. I am cursed already for what I did CALL NOT his ghost to curse me more.
Though he was my BROTHER he took my share of things and made it HIS.
To these woods he came to flee my VENGEANCE.
TILEN WAS HIS NAME MAY HE NEVER WAKE.

As a witch, <FirstName> was more comfortable with uncanny things than most people. Even so, <his/her> blood ran cold.

Tilen...No wonder he was afraid. Down the hole was his own skeleton, its skull smashed in by a jealous brother.

The temperature in the cavern dropped. What was slick with moisture went slick with ice. At the same time, <FirstName> felt the lodestone <he/she>'d just picked up burning like a hot coal in <his/her> pocket.

"How many years did I sleep here and dream
I slept upstairs? My brother's dead by now,
All his vengeance spent, long past, and mine's 
Long overdue. I hope his children's children
Keep their windows open...I will gnaw their bones."

The ghost vanished.

A huge black dog took its place. It howled and leapt through the hole in the cavern roof, leaving <FirstName> alone with Tilen's bones.
The young witch clutched <his/her> stomach and almost collapsed. Knott caught <him/her> before <he/she> did.
Knott knew what to do. He tore the papers and broke the alder twigs. He hurled the flasks against the cavern wall.
Tilen was no witch, and the items shouldn't have had any effect on him. A different uneasiness came to <FirstName> now as <he/she> looked at the bones.
There was a knapsack, stiff with moisture, and a bow and quiver full of arrows.
[Woodcraft] Though old, the bow might be a useful weapon. <He/She> examined it.

It was carved from yew -- well-carved, too. <He/She> took it.

The arrows had a dusting of magic. The work of Jad Bizunta or witchcraft, they would be useful. <He/She> took the quiver.

Inside was a vial of blueflask (famous for its shelf life) that the young witch pocketed. <He/She> also noticed a curious rock flecked with yellow -- a lodestone, <he/she> decided, absentmindedly pocketing that too. As <he/she> did, <he/she> felt a chill.

That's when <he/she> noticed a piece of parchment in the skeleton's bony hands.
The parchment was moldy but still legible. The writing on it was in a rough, unskilled hand. This is what it said:
<He/She> saw a knapsack stiff with moisture.

Inside was a vial of blueflask (famous for its shelf life) that the young witch pocketed. <He/She> also noticed a curious rock flecked with yellow -- a lodestone, <he/she> decided, absentmindedly pocketing that too. As <he/she> did, <he/she> felt a chill.

That's when <he/she> noticed a piece of parchment in the skeleton's bony hands.
[Folk Magic] But the young witch had remedies for simple charms like this.
<FirstName> stamped <his/her> foot three times and spat.
The cords around the alder branches slithered away like snakes, and the witch hunters' nonsense burst into flame. The flasks of hexbane cracked and blackened with mold.
Tilen was no witch, and the items shouldn't have had any effect on him. A different uneasiness came to <FirstName> now as <he/she> looked at the bones.
<He/She> summoned all <his/her> willpower to try to sweep away the charms <him/her>self.
[Success: Wisdom 15] <FirstName> scattered the damnable things across the floor. <He/She> still felt uncomfortable, but <he/she>'d dispersed the potent aura they'd had all gathered together.
[Failure: Wisdom too low] <He/She> couldn't do it. <He/She> keeled over, clutching <his/her> stomach.
Knott knew what to do. He tore the papers and broke the alder twigs. He hurled the flasks against the cavern wall.

<He/She> felt a wave of repulsion and stepped back as if struck. The bones were strewn with charms against witchcraft. Very old charms, but still potent. Powdered hexbane, pages from witch hunters' tracts, alder branches tied into X's with leathern cords.

The heap was once a single skeleton. Part of the skull was missing, and the rest was crushed. This person had met a violent end. Moldering rags clung to the bones. Something about the pile made <FirstName> uneasy. Did Tilen know about this? Was it the source of his apprehension?
